greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = A019565(A003188(n)).
comment: A squarefree analog of A207901 (and the subsequence consisting of its squarefree terms): Each term is either a divisor or a multiple of the next one, and the terms differ by a single prime factor. Compare also to A284003.

For all n >= 0, max(a(n + 1), a(n)) / min(a(n + 1), a(n)) = A094290(n + 1) = prime(valuation(n + 1, 2) + 1) = A000040(A001511(n + 1)). [See _Russ Cox_'s Dec 04 2010 comment in A007814.] - _David A. Corneth_ & _Antti Karttunen_, Apr 16 2018
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..8191
mathematica: Array[Times @@ Prime@ Flatten@ Position[#, 1] &@ Reverse@ IntegerDigits[BitXor[#, Floor[#/2]], 2] &, 72, 0] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Apr 27 2018 *)
program: A019565(n) = {my(j); factorback(Mat(vector(if(n, #n=vecextract(binary(n), "-1..1")), j, [prime(j), n[j]])~))}; \\ From A019565
(PARI) first(n) = {my(pr = primes(1 + logint(n, 2)), ex = vector(#pr, i, 1), res = vector(n)); res[1] = 1; for(i = 1, n-1, v = valuation(i, 2); res[i + 1] = res[i] * pr[v++] ^ ex[v]; ex[v]*=-1); res}
xref: A permutation of A005117. Subsequence of A207901.
Cf. A302054 (gives the sum of prime divisors).
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_ & _Peter Munn_, Apr 16 2018
